aboutSummit.title: <primary>The Regional Ecological Summit 2026</primary> is aimed at shaping a shared vision for the sustainable development of Central Asia.
aboutSummit.text1: The Summit aims to unite Central Asian countries in partnership with the UN to develop agreed solutions to climate and environmental challenges. This is a two-year process (2024–2026) that has received broad international and political support. The Summit's concept is based on the idea of "Bir Tamyr" ("Same Root") - a symbol of common heritage and collective action for a sustainable future of the region.
aboutSummit.text2: We live in an era when innovation and sustainable development are becoming the most important priorities. At our summit, you will be able to see how cutting-edge ideas and solutions can change the world for the better. We invite you to become part of this movement to build together a future that inspires and motivates.

programms.title: Program
programms.text: Every day at RES 2026 will bring inspiration, discoveries and opportunities for cooperation. Follow the most important moments and learn about unique events such as evening events, networking sessions and awards for the best innovative projects.

speakers.text: The best minds of our time will gather at RES 2026.
speakers.text1: We are proud to be able to present on our platform world leaders in technology, sustainable development and science. Our speakers are those who shape the future by making the most important decisions that change the world.

partners.text1: These leading organizations play a key role in shaping this unique event and enable us to showcase the most advanced ideas.

about.title: About the summit
about.presidentTextTitle: Quote by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan:
about.presidentText: «Many LLDCs face water scarcity, glacier loss, desertification and other extreme weather events. Addressing these challenges requires coordinated regional efforts and strong international support. At the same time, I believe that climate action must remain balanced and inclusive, matching the legitimate development needs of nations. To strengthen our joint climate efforts, I invite all of you to take part at the Regional Ecological Summit to be held in Astana in partnership with the United Nations in April next year».
about.presidentInitiativeText:
"However, development cannot be sustainable without addressing the climate crisis. Central Asia is one of the regions most vulnerable to climate change on the planet. Warming here occurs twice as fast as the global average. In response, we are promoting a pragmatic and regionally coordinated climate agenda. Our commitments include participation in various international organizations and agreements. 

 In 2026, Kazakhstan, in partnership with the UN, will hold a Regional Ecological Summit, which is intended to become a platform for uniting Central Asian strategies and global ambitions".
about.presidentPosition: From the speech of Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, President of the Republic of Kazakhstan, at the Third United Nations Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries, Turkmenistan, Awaza, 2025
about.text2: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026, initiated by the President of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, aims to unite Central Asian countries in partnership with the UN to develop agreed solutions to climate and environmental challenges. This is a two-year process (2024–2026) that has received broad international and political support. The Summit's concept is based on the idea of "Bir Tamyr" ("Same Root") - a symbol of common heritage and collective action for a sustainable future of the region.
about.text3: In partnership with the United Nations and other international organizations, the Regional Ecological Summit 2026 will bring together the countries of Central Asia to develop coordinated solutions on climate and environmental issues. The Summit will address topics such as the preservation of the Aral Sea and the reduction of the Caspian Sea basin, the promotion of green finance and low-carbon technologies, as well as the development of joint initiatives, declarations, and a 2026–2030 Action Programme for the sustainable development of the region.
about.aboutText1: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 was initiated by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev and aims to unite Central Asian countries to develop common solutions to combat climate change in partnership with the UN. This is not just a meeting - it is a two-year preparation process that started in 2024 and culminates in a high-level Summit in 2026, where agreed environmental initiatives and mechanisms for regional cooperation will be presented.
about.aboutText2: The United Nations expressed its support for the Summit through General Assembly Resolution 78/147 of 19 December 2023, entitled “Central Asia facing environmental challenges: strengthening regional solidarity for sustainable development and prosperity.”
about.aboutText3: In 2024, the initiative was also reflected in a number of key political documents at the level of Heads of State, including:
about.aboutText31: the Karabakh Declaration of the Informal Summit of the Organization of Turkic States (6 July 2024, Azerbaijan);
about.aboutText32: the Joint Statement of the Sixth Consultative Meeting of the Heads of State of Central Asia (9 August 2024, Kazakhstan);
about.aboutText33: the Bishkek Declaration of the Eleventh Summit of the Organization of Turkic States (6 November 2024, Kyrgyz Republic).
about.aboutText34:
In 2025, the initiative received further recognition during the opening ceremony of the UN Regional Centre for the Sustainable Development Goals for Central Asia and Afghanistan, as well as during the Third United Nations Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries (Turkmenistan), held with the participation of the UN Secretary-General, António Guterres. 

 RES 2026 aims to bring together the countries of Central Asia to develop common solutions to combat climate change and address environmental challenges, in partnership with the United Nations and international organizations. Particular attention will be given to identifying the region’s actual needs for green financing aimed at supporting adaptation measures, advancing low-carbon technologies, and strengthening environmental resilience across the region. The Summit provides a regional platform for dialogue and solidarity, enhancing cooperation among states, international organizations, scientific communities, and the business sector. It contributes to raising awareness of priority environmental issues, identifying practical solutions, and developing joint action plans for the future, aimed at the sustainable development of the region.
about.aboutText4:
"However, development cannot be sustainable without addressing the climate crisis. Central Asia is one of the regions most vulnerable to climate change on the planet. Warming here occurs twice as fast as the global average. In response, we are promoting a pragmatic and regionally coordinated climate agenda. Our commitments include participation in various international organizations and agreements. 

 In 2026, Kazakhstan, in partnership with the UN, will hold a Regional Ecological Summit, which is intended to become a platform for uniting Central Asian strategies and global ambitions".
about.aboutText5:
The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 in partnership with the UN is a platform for uniting Central Asian countries in developing agreed working solutions and mechanisms that reflect a regional approach to overcoming climate and environmental challenges, including the tragedy of the Aral Sea, which has become a global symbol of environmental degradation, and the steady decline in the level of the Caspian Sea. Special attention will be paid to the formation of real needs of Central Asia in 'green' financing aimed at supporting adaptation measures, developing low-carbon technologies and strengthening the environmental sustainability of the region. 

 The Summit creates a regional platform for dialogue and solidarity, strengthening cooperation between states, international organizations, scientific and business communities. It contributes to raising awareness of priority environmental issues, finding practical solutions and forming joint action plans for the future aimed at sustainable development of the region. The goal is to form specific initiatives and mechanisms for joint action. Adoption of the Joint Declaration of Heads of State of Central Asia on regional cooperation in ecology and sustainable development. 

 Approval of the Regional Action Program with UN agencies (2026–2030) for a sustainable future of Central Asia, including regional initiatives on thematic areas of the Summit, launch of new environmental projects and initiatives in the directions of the Summit. Preparation for the summit began in 2024 and includes a series of regional consultations. The Summit will be the culmination of this process and will give political impetus to the environmental agenda of the region. The initiative strengthens the existing efforts of countries, complementing them with a regional dimension. The basis will be a coordinated environmental agenda, including updated climate goals of Central Asian countries.
about.resText1: The 2026 Sustainable Development Goals (SDC) was initiated by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, at the 78th UN General Assembly in September 2023. At the Astana International Forum in May 2025, the expansion of the agenda from climate to environmental was announced.
about.resText2: The initiative's image is reflected in the phrase "Bir Tamyr" (Same Roots). The word "tamyr" exists in almost all the region's languages and carries a profound image: roots represent a shared history and connection to nature; veins symbolize the pulse and movement within the region, the interweaving of vessels, spirit, and culture. It is a metaphor for connection, sustainability, and a shared heritage that unites Central Asia not by political borders, but by meaning, memory, and future. Visually, the image of the Central Asian countries is reflected in the Summit's emblem (logo): different in shape, color, and character, yet standing side by side as a symbol of unity in diversity. A reference to the shape of a barcode also symbolizes a unified space for dialogue and action, modern approaches, innovation, and technological solutions. The Summit reflects this image: one region—common challenges—collective action. It will unite states, international organizations, the scientific community, businesses, the civil society, and youth to lay the foundation for a shared, environmentally sustainable future.
about.resText3: Preparations for the Summit began in 2024 and include a series of regional consultations.

kazakhstan.title: About Kazakhstan
kazakhstan.text1:
Kazakhstan is the largest country in the world that does not have direct access to the World Ocean. Most of the country's territory is made up of deserts – 44% and semi-deserts-14%. Steppes occupy 26% of the area of Kazakhstan, forests-5.5%. There are 8,5 thousand rivers in the country. 

 The north-eastern part of the Caspian Sea is part of the republic. The Aral Sea is divided between Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. There are 48 thousand large and small lakes in Kazakhstan. The largest of them are Balkhash, Zaisan and Alakol. The distance from the oceans determines the sharply continental climate of the country. 

 The administrative and territorial structure of the country includes
kazakhstan.climateText: is sharply continental, with large temperature fluctuations between summer and winter, dry air and low precipitation. All four seasons are pronounced here: cold winters, hot dry summers, short and changeable spring, and warm autumn. In the north, winters are harsher (temperatures can drop to -45 °C) and summers are warmer; in the south, winters are milder (near zero) and summers are hotter, with daytime temperatures up to +40°C and above.

etc.strategicVisionIntro: Kazakhstan has adopted the following Strategic Documents:

strategicDocuments.0: Strategy for achieving Carbon Neutrality until 2060, Road Map to the Strategy
strategicDocuments.1: IT AIMS to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 17% from 1990 levels by 2035
strategicDocuments.2: Concepts for the transition of the Republic of Kazakhstan to a «green economy»
strategicDocuments.3: The concept of managing all types of waste for 2026-2030
strategicDocuments.4: The concept of conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity will cover the period from 2025 to 2035

nationalInitiativesIntro.text1: Support for investment projects financed through utilization fee revenues.
nationalInitiativesIntro.text2: Incentive payments to support waste collection, sorting, and recycling.
nationalInitiativesIntro.text3: the first in Central Asia, providing for the introduction of digital tracking of all waste streams and the establishment of a National Waste Management Operator.

nationalInitiatives.text1: is a large-scale national environmental campaign under the auspices of the Presidentof the Republic of Kazakhstan K. Tokayev, aimed at creating an ecological culture through cleaning territories (settlements, natural objects, banks of reservoirs), planting trees (millions of seedlings) and combating unauthorized landfills, involving young people, business and government agencies, with a focus on waste management, innovation and landscaping.
nationalInitiatives.text2: is an initiative in Kazakhstan, with the aim of creating woodlands until 2025, and then extended until 2027. The goal is to plant and sow $ 2 billion. saplings of tree and shrub species, including saxaul, pine, birch and others, in the state forest fund to restore forests and improve the ecological situation.
nationalInitiatives.title3: The International Fund for Biodiversity Conservation
nationalInitiatives.text3: is an initiative of Kazakhstan that will unite the efforts of states, international organizations (UNDP, UNESCO, FAO) and NGOs to finance the protection of ecosystems, develop ecotourism, introduce eco-technologies and raise awareness, working according to the best international standards for sustainable development and conservation of flora and fauna.
nationalInitiatives.text4: The <bold>UN Regional Center for Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for Central Asia and Afghanistan has been established in Kazakhstan (Almaty).</bold> It was approved by the UN member states in March 2025, opened in August 2025, and its goal is to contribute to the achievement of 17 global SDGs by 2030.

preparationProcess.title: Preparatory process
preparationProcess.subtitle: The Summit was preceded by a two-year preparatory process focused on shaping its substantive agenda and expanding the network of partners.
preparationProcess.text: In 2025 alone, eleven major regional and international consultations were held at key environmental fora, including the 62nd sessions of the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice and the Subsidiary Body for Implementation (SB 62) of the UNFCCC in Bonn, Germany; the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York, USA; COP30 in Belém, Brazil; and the seventh session of the United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA-7) in Nairobi, Kenya.
